children.text:
So, code outline:

program atcoder_AGC027_A
    implicit none
    integer :: N, x, i, num
    integer, allocatable :: sweet(:)
    read(*, *) N, x
    allocate(sweet(N)) do i = 1, N
        read(*, *) sweet(i)
    end do
    call sort_array(sweet)
    num = 0 do i = 1, N
        if (x - sweet(num+1) >= 0) then
            x = x - sweet(num+1)
            num = num + 1
        else
            exit
        end if
    end do
    if (num == N .and. x > 0) then
        num = num - 1
    end if
    print *, num
contains
    subroutine sort_array(arr)
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
        integer :: i, j, temp
        do i = 1, size(arr) - 1
            do j = i + 1, size(arr) if (arr(i) > arr(j)) then
                    temp = arr(i)
                    arr(i) = arr(j)
                    arr(j) = temp
                end if
            end do
        end do
    end subroutine sort_array
end program atcoder_AGC027_A

children.text:
In Fortran, the kind parameter for 8-byte integers can vary. Some compilers use kind=8, others kind=8. So assuming that we can use integer(kind=8). So, modifying the code:

program atcoder_AGC027_A
    implicit none
    integer :: N
    integer(kind=8) :: x  ! to match Java's long
    integer :: i, num
    integer(kind=8), allocatable :: sweet(:)
    read(*, *) N, x
    allocate(sweet(N)) do i = 1, N
        read(*, *) sweet(i)
    end do
    call sort_array(sweet)
    num = 0 do i = 1, N
        if (x - sweet(num+1) >= 0) then
            x = x - sweet(num+1)
            num = num + 1
        else
            exit
        end if
    end do
    if (num == N .and. x > 0) then
        num = num - 1
    end if
    print *, num
contains
    subroutine sort_array(arr)
        integer(kind=8), intent(inout) :: arr(:)
        integer :: i, j
        integer(kind=8) : : temp
        do i = 1, size(arr) - 1
            do j = i + 1, size(arr) if (arr(i) > arr(j)) then
                    temp = arr(i)
                    arr(i) = arr(j)
                    arr(j) = temp
                end if
            end do
        end do
    end subroutine sort_array
end program atcoder_AGC027_A

This way, x and the elements of sweet are 8-byte integers, which matches Java's long. But how does Fortran handle reading integers into 8-byte variables?

For programming competition problems, if the sum of all elements exceeds 2^31-1, then using 32-bit integers would overflow. But in Fortran, if we use integer(kind=8) for x and the sweet array, that would handle larger numbers. However, the original code uses Java's long, which is 64-bit. So in Fortran, to match this, perhaps we need to use 8-byte integers.

So, perhaps variables x and sweet should be integer(kind=8). Let me adjust that.

In Fortran, the kind parameter for 8-byte integers can vary. Some compilers use kind=8, others kind=8. So assuming that we can use integer(kind=8).

So, modifying the code:

program atcoder_AGC027_A
    implicit none
    integer :: N
    integer(kind=8) :: x  ! to match Java's long
    integer :: i, num
    integer(kind=8), allocatable :: sweet(:)
    read(*, *) N, x
    allocate(sweet(N))
    do i = 1, N
        read(*, *) sweet(i)
    end do
    call sort_array(sweet)
    num = 0
    do i = 1, N
        if (x - sweet(num+1) >= 0) then
            x = x - sweet(num+1)
            num = num + 1
        else
            exit
        end if
    end do
    if (num == N .and. x > 0) then
        num = num - 1
    end if
    print *, num
contains
    subroutine sort_array(arr)
        integer(kind=8), intent(inout) :: arr(:)
        integer :: i, j
        integer(kind=8) :: temp
        do i = 1, size(arr) - 1
            do j = i + 1, size(arr)
                if (arr(i) > arr(j)) then
                    temp = arr(i)
                    arr(i) = arr(j)
                    arr(j) = temp
                end if
            end do
        end do
    end subroutine sort_array
end program atcoder_AGC027_A

This way, x and the elements of sweet are 8-byte integers, which matches Java's long.
